By MEL SHUSTER
Two members of the Students
for a Democratic Society were
refused admission to the closed,
held
Oft-the-record
seminar
Saturday with Secretary of State
Dean Rusk when they refused
to promise to keep secret the nature and content of the discussion.

Chairman of Hopkins SDS, and
David Harding were present at
the invitation of the Hopkins
administration, and had they
been admitted, they would have
been the sole undergraduates at
the meeting. The two arrived
With a tape recorder, and announced their intention to record and publicize the details of
the meeting.
Asked to leave the machine
behind, they accented, but requested to take notes. This re-

ROTC
Honors
The United States Army inaugurated this summer its new
Program.
Scholarship
ROTC
Three Johns Hopkins juniors
Were among 600 to receive these
awards, which pay for all tuition,
textbooks and other fees. In addition the cadets receive a subsistence allowance of $50 monthly for the duration of the scholarship.
The three honored ROTC
Cadets, all members of the National Society of Pershing Rifles,
an elite military organization affiliated wth the ROTC and
founded in 1894 by General John
J. Pershing to promote American
Citizenship and to further the
highest ideals of the military
Drofession, are Steven A. Mason,
Alexander Davidoff and George
V. Stelzenmuller. These men
have completed two years of college and ROTC training and
Were nominated by a board from
the University. The board conflicted of two thembers of the
University Administration, two
ROTC instructors and the highest ranking ROTC cadet. Final
eelections were made by a board
Of senior officers in the Depart!tient of the Army, who chose
only one out of every ten applications submitted from throughout the nation.
A freshman, Peter E. Brownback, was one of 400 high school
graduates selected to receive a
four year scholarship.

Chivalry Alive
In,Fraternty
By JAMES HENRY
Hysterical feminine screams
interrupted a late night snack of
three brothers of the Alpha
Delta Phi of 3004 North Calvert
Street.
Brothers Robert O'Connor,
Gregory Altshuh and Charles
Sheridan raced from their kitchen into the back alley to catch
sight of a woman sprinting up
three flights of dimly lit stairs
to her apartment. The trio then
man
spotted a middle-aged
sneaking down the alley in the
shadows and, assuming foulplay, opted to investigate.
The team was reduced to a
membership of two when Brother O'Connor, overwhelmed with
tension, tripped in the driveway
and sprained his ankle.
While Altshuh and Sheridan
continued the chase, a fourth
brother, Evan Wilson, spotted
the action from a St. Paul Street
porch and volunteered to notify
the authorities. Soon afterward
a half-dozen police cars jammed
Calvert Alley where Wilson stood
alone to greet them. Only
through the shrewdest powers of
negotiation was Wilson able to
convince the officers that they
were not victims of a collegiate
prank.
The suspect, who had reached
Greenmount
Avenue, sought
momentary relief in the restroom of a neighborhood tavern.
Sheridan, considering the temper
of the establishment, elected to
wait outside while police arrived
to apprehend the prowler.
The Northern District Police
and the Ace Elastic bandage
company combined to bring the
situation well under control. The
suspect claimed that, he had entered the woman's parked car
looking "for a peaceful night's
rest."
On Tuesday, October 19 in the
County Court, North Maryland
District at 9:00 A.M., the suspect
was found guilty of vagrancy
and is currently serving a sixtyday sentence in the city jail.

quest was refused by Robert
McCloskey, press officer for the
State Department, who explained that "only under such conditions could Dean Rusk be more
honest — or, as we say in the
candid."
Department,
State
Dawidowicz and Harding then
left, since, according to Dawidowicz, "We could not in good
conscience enter under the pretense of keeping quiet, and later
publicize the discussion."
Although it was finely agreed
upon to send representatives, a
number of SDS members expressed disapproval of the invitation
at a gathering Thersday of approximately half of the chapter.
It was felt that attending the
closed session with Rusk might
be construed as tacit SDS approval of such seminars, which
the organization has strongly
denounced. Furthermore, some
believed that the hour-long
period would result in little more
than a statement by Rusk of Administration policy, with little
opportunity for positive contributions by the others present.
Finally. Dawidowicz stated, it
was suggested that the Hopkins
administration was attempting
to placate SDS, and that it had
only granted a question-answer
period at Rusk's lecture at the
last moment, and as a result of
strong pressure from SDS.
Ross Jones, executive assistant to Hopkins President Milton
Eisenhower, explained that the
Invitation was "a genuine effort
to allow representatives from
SDS to participate in an interesting and beneficial discussion
with Secretary Rusk." The undergraduates would have been
admitted, he said, since SDS has
exhibited such intense interest
in Rusk's visit. He also stated
that the two SDS members had
been chosen for no other reason
than their prominence in SIXS
activities at Hopkins.

HOT DAMN. VIET-NAM
If Dean Husk was to be the Pied Piper of Washington, to appease the Hopkins intelligentsia who have
plagued him as did the "rats of Hamlin", to bring the
dissenting scholars into the swing of Viet Nam Policy,
then his horn was surely out of tune; for in the formal
part of his speech, he didn't blow anything but his cool.
This doesn't mean that his appearance did not
bring on a festive Friday the fifteenth. But it does mean
that midst the clamour of the gala political afternoon,
few people paid any attention to the Pied's feeble horn.
It was Internatipnal Peace Week and 'experts" predicted that Athens, Paris, Pittsburgh and Baltimore
would he the stage for one of the largest Communist
rallies in History.
There were week-long rumors that the Communists
had infiltrated the Hopkins' radical ranks, and the News
American, "the people's paper", took advantage of a
sympathetic local public to splash what looked to them
like red all around the primmed Homewood green.
A little old lady, her face liberally roughed red,
cut a mean and rather contrary political rug as she
marched, American flag in hand, into the ring of protestors.
Everyone got a laugh out of the young fellow who
stuck a sign in the air which put Communism down in
very obscene terms; probably his was the only attestation that everyone fully understood or at least agreed
with. Ile was later detained by the police.
And at the same time that Charles Capper, in a
post-address forum in Levering Hall, was reading the
writing on the wall in technicolor, and Dr. Peabody was
reading from a Washington-reflected mirror in black
and white, the Secretary of State, Dean Rusk had made
the following announcement:
"Cooperative research in radiation sterilization Technique is resulting in the elimination of the screwworm from doe Island of Curacao, and the United States
scientists are currently participating in studies in Central America, in which irradiation techniques are being
employed in the control of the Mediterranean fruit fly."
The audience snickered behind the Piper's back.

MOTOR SPORTS

Road Test:'49 Ford Convertible

One too many mornings follows one too many beers

With the advent of new and
radical designs on the American
automotive market, one is often
tempted to seek the sure and
the steady, the car with conventional drive, which offers the
many comforts of modern technology, yet can be depended
upon to go. One such is the famous classic which has become
an automotive legend in its own
time, the world famous 1949
Super Torque SSK flat head V-8,
independent suspension Ford
Deluxe, sometimes
Roadster
known as the '49 Ford.
In order to ,acquaint our readers with the many wonders of
this car, it was our rare privilege to drive such a vehicle, since
only a few are in existence. This
was not a limited production car
by any means, so the scarcity of
the model is accounted to hoarding by collectors and museums,
as well as scrap metal processing
concerns.
The first thing one notices
upon approaching the automobile, besides the smell of oil, is
the striking design of the coachwork, and the obvious care with
which the automobile was con-

structed. On notices that in the
ancient Ford tradition, the body
has rotted out in a symmetrical,
artistically coherent pattern,
giving the car great unity of design. The rusted-through areas
serve to ventilate the passenger
and engine compartments with a
continuous flow of fresh, cold
air—a welcome change, we note,
from the artiflcally-treated air
one is forced to breathe in modern automobiles. The paint is, of
course, the finest lacquer, and
its unique patina would be hard
to duplicate in any but the most
expensive auto finishes. The
hood ornament, a classic in
its own right, is the famous
Ford "Plastic Hunk", so popular in the late forties and early
fifties—up to the Civil War.
Its design represents the freedom
of speed and motion, and the
integrity inherent in this proud
steed of the highways.
No discussion of the outer car
would be complete without a
thorough examination of the fine
removable top. Many radical design features have been incorporated in its production. In
answer to an oft-heard corn-

plaint that the top refuses to go
down through motor malfunction, the possibility of such malfunction has been precluded by
the elimination of the motor. In
a sweeping change in top construction concept, Ford's top
goes up and down by hand.
Great on all but the rainiest
days. An equally radical design
feature is the use of dependable
grey canvas to replace easilytearing vinyl. Kudos on these
two great accomplishments.
Let us now turn to the technical aspects of this rarest of
all great cars. The motor is the
famous flat-head V-8, which
turns 428 b.h.p. at 7200 RPM,but
unfortunately has its redline at
The
3000.
great
potential
In this design, it seems, was
never developed, As it is, we
had to rate the mill at 71.356
b.h.p. This is, of course, a rough
approximation. Even at this
modest horsepower rating, performance was amazing. In its
first run the car went 9-60 and
back in 9.8 seconds. This occurred, however, when it was
inadvertently driven off a cliff

=-REPUBLICAN BIAS

The Beginning Or The End
By JEOPFRY LEBAR
The Republican failure at the
Polls in 1964 may have been the
beginning or the ending of a
Political party. The mere fact
that it is in the past does not
remove it from the present. It
Will affect future American political history as much as have
the gmat wars and depressions.
The "linage" of the Republican
Party cannot be restored to "the
Party of responsibility" now by
Madison avenue techniques or
even by our able political medieine man, Ray Bliss.
The Republican party needs
the intellectual and collegiate
Mind to express its thoughts. It
needs the minds and plans of
those who read this column. The
American political system needs
the eloquence of an Adlai
Stevenson or the prosaic turn of
the word of a John Kennedy
froni the Republican side of the
aisle. We, Young Republicans,
as authors of this column, intend to treat the daily issues
from a quasi-intellectual view
Point.
The Republican party Is a
Political party whose sole concern is with the governing of
this country and its relations
With other countries. The RePublican party is not an organization created to grind out dogma on theoretical issues. Its doctrines cannot and should not extend out of the practical and
Material. With this attitude, a
Political party will lose most of
its Intellectual support from the
beginning. However, the ideals,
beliefs, and convictions of the
individual can be transformed
into reality through political
Parties. The Democratic Party,
although not completely successful at this, has kindled the enthusiasm of the intellectual
community more than the RePublican party. Enough for political philosophy
Dr. Mandelbaum, Professor in
"Philosophic Classics and Problems" (courses which I heartily

recommend) once remarked to
me that if one thoroughly learned moral and ethical philosophy,
political philosophy could be
figured out on a slide-rule. All
the more power to him.
Let's start with the issue of
honesty in government. This issue could hardly save Barry
Goldwater's campaign from the
stigma of World War III, segregation, or poverty for everyone
over 65. But historically and
certainly in practice today, the
Republican party has been the
cleaner of the two parties. The
absconding New York mayor,
Jimmie Walker, was succeeded
by a LaGuardia. The Hague's,
the Prentergast's, the Tweed's,
the De Sapio's, and the Bobby
Baker's are in the tradition of
machine politics and all happen
to be Democrats. The Republicans cannot be particularly
proud of the Ulysses Grant administration after the Civil War,
or the Sherman Adams vicuna
coat incident. By and large, however, the openness of political
opinion and the unregimented,
individualistic attitude of Republicans does not lead to absolute
control of the party in any one
place. Therefore, corruption under the eagle eye of the Democratic leaders is quite a difficult
thing for Republicans.
But does this really matter?
Read the speeches of President
Johnson
and
other Democratic leaders. Their platforms
do not include promises of clean
government. They don't deny

PAGE SEVEN

NEWS-LETTER

I

scandals in their programs for
the impoverished: Mobilisation
for Youth, HARYOU, etc. Johnson never assures his people that
his administration is made up of
men free from temptation. Apparently he doesn't have to. The
people are basically uninterested.
Scandal and corruption have
been the cost of progress in the
past and the habit has not been
broken.
A Republican victory in the
field of ethics in government
would probably be the most
vital victory of all. If Republicans were elected and agreed to
carry out every social program
of the Democratic party in an
honest and professional way, the
Republican party would have
much to be proud of and the
country would have much to
gain.
Rather than attempting to
destroy any social legislation
that our Democratic brethren
may have stumbled upon, the
Republican aim should be to
clean it up, make it just, remove
the "pork-barrel", elminate the
fraud, and uncover the Bobby
Bakers. It isn't glamorous. It
isn't very conservative or very
liberal or very exciting. It may
not get many votes, but it will
mean better government. And,
as the car owner quickly learns
the difference in quality between
the Allstate and Prudential Insurance Company, the voter will
learn the differences between the
quality of the Democrat and
Republican parties.

Labor And Johnson's Great Consensus

I

by CHARLES CAPPER
With the emergence of the national corporation around the
turn of the century, the trend
toward a progressively centralized economy marked the inevitable corollary of American industrialization. The competition
of small firms gave way to the
concentration of the basic decisions of production and distribution into a small number of
corporations.
proBefore World War
gressives looked to government
as a force capable of ensuring
the "public responsibility" of
corporations. But even the progressive Wilson administration,
In spite of its election pronouncements, quickly realized what
Theodore Roosevelt had learned
—that the government, lacking
any real economic power of its
own, could only co-operate with,
and not coerce, the corporate
rulers of American economic life.
Even during the first deof
Franklin
years
pression
Roosevelt's administration, the

government could experiment
with programs of social legislation only so far as they did not
threaten corporation rule.
In fact, Roosevelt's first legislation, the key to his first New
Deal recovery program—the National Industrial Recovery Act—
was concerned with legalizing,
co-operating with, and helping
to extend the concentration of
economic power into the hands
of progressively fewer corporations.
But the 30's also gave birth to
the first real challenge to the
economic power of the giant
corporations—organized labor on
an industry wide basis.
In making economic decisions,
such as wages and working conditions, corporations had to take
into increasingly greater account
the power of their organized
workers, wielding the weapon of
strike.
But even these economic decisions in a highly centralized
and industrialized economy had

to be viewed in the context of
larger economic and political
questions. Higher wages secured
from an employer become meaningless for workers thrown out
of work because of technological
unemployment.
The right to strike, the ultimate economic .power of organized labor, becomes meaningless
when the government, as under
the Taft-Hartley Act, continually
intervenes to suppress strikes in
major industries.
Consequently, in order to preserve its power as a labor movement, labor is forced to act politically—to preserve those gains
made across the bargaining table
and to gain those benefits only a
healthy economy can provide.
The political mechanism traditionally utilized by labor since
the 30's has been the Democratic
party.
Without discussing the historical evolution of this relationship
between the Democratic party
and the organized labor movement, we can only focus on the
most recent developments in
terms of the Johnson administration.
On every Great Society bill—
poverty, education. medicare,
beautification — labor worked
hard for President Johnson. In
return labor sought three 'goals—
repeal of Section 14b of the
Taft-Hartley Act (which now
permits states to outlaw compulsory unionism), higher minimum wage, and liberalization of
the unemployment compensation
system. They got none.

The reaction of labor leaders
to this political orphanage was
summed up by one labor lobbyist
at a meeting of leaders on October 11: "President Johnson has
passed a lot of bills, but they're
all concensus bills — backed by
business as well as labor. He's
not pushing a single bill really
tough for big business to swallow." But even more important
than this recognition of labor's
political impotence within the
Democratic party is the leadership's rationalization and remedy for such impotence.
In the first place, the strength
of organized labor has been significantly lessened since World
War II. Union membership has
often declined in relation to the
work force; organizing campaigns (particularly in the potentially powerful white collar
sector) have been weak. Related
to this quantitative decline has
been a decline of militancy.
Union leaders cannot rally the
political militancy of the rankand-file against Johnson because
these same leaders are almost
daily involved in suppressing
shop militancy, selling company
contracts to discontented workers, and generally playing the
role of Johnson's ambassadors to
the working class. And finally,
the labor leadership is so tied to
the Democratic party that the
ultimate threat to Johnson—a
party bolt—is out of the question.
As the Washington correspondents, Evans and Novack, point
out, "With all its grievances, big
labor isn't about to say anything
out loud criticizing President
Johnson ... It has nowhere else
to go." More correctly, labor
leadership has nowhere else to
go.
Whether or not the rank-andfile workers of the unions continue to tolerate this organizational stagnation, suppression of
economic militancy, and political impotence, is another question.

By BARRON WORMSER
Boasting an impressive 3-0 log,
the varsity crosscountry team
will face a tough Franklin and
Marshall squad tomorrow afternoon at Homewood.
As the two teams are evenly
matched; the physical condition
of John Sopka, who is nursing
an injury, could play an important role in determining the final
Outcome.
The Jays, who met Gettysburg
Wednesday, notched a pair of
wins last Saturday in a triangular meet against Haverford
and Drexel. Sparked by the brilliant running of Kevin Murphy,
the harriers turned back Haverford, 26-31; and Drexel, 23-33.
Murphy's determined performance was especially exceptional
due to the fact that he had
missed practice for the entire
week because of an ankle injury.
Get Decision
The third win in the Blue Jays'
victory column was the result
of the decision of the Hopkins
and Loyola directors concerning
the disputed October 9th meet
with the Greyhounds. The .claim
lodged against Hopkins runner
John Sopka was turned down,
thus giving the Jays a 27-30 victory.
The coach of the undefeated
Polanowski,
Ed
hill'n'dalers,
stated that he was very pleased
with the team's showing so far
and was especially happy about
the great improvement shown by
Jack Loomis and Cliff Cyr.
Frosh Win
Swinging over to the freshman
squad, the coach noted the exceptional ability of fledgling
harriers Jeff Lauren:, John Gardner, Ralph Hingson, and Ronnie
Teeter; along with three or four
other runners who have shown
good potential. As the varsity
contingent will lose three of its
top men in June, the performance of the freshmen is especially important.
The frosh, sporting a 1-0 record, faced Bel Air High School
Tuesday and meet Bainbridge
Prep, today at Homewood. In
racking up their initial win over
Mergenthaler Vocational Technical High School, 16-41; the
Baby Jays took seven of the first
eight places. Top time was
posted by Jeff Lauren, who negotiated the course in 10:38.

Chivalry Alive
In,Fraternty
By JAMES HENRY
Hysterical feminine screams
interrupted a late night snack of
three brothers of the Alpha
Delta Phi of 3004 North Calvert
Street.
Brothers Robert O'Connor,
Gregory Altshuh and Charles
Sheridan raced from their kitchen into the back alley to catch
sight of a woman sprinting up
three flights of dimly lit stairs
to her apartment. The trio then
man
spotted a middle-aged
sneaking down the alley in the
shadows and, assuming foulplay, opted to investigate.
The team was reduced to a
membership of two when Brother O'Connor, overwhelmed with
tension, tripped in the driveway
and sprained his ankle.
While Altshuh and Sheridan
continued the chase, a fourth
brother, Evan Wilson, spotted
the action from a St. Paul Street
porch and volunteered to notify
the authorities. Soon afterward
a half-dozen police cars jammed
Calvert Alley where Wilson stood
alone to greet them. Only
through the shrewdest powers of
negotiation was Wilson able to
convince the officers that they
were not victims of a collegiate
prank.
The suspect, who had reached
Greenmount
Avenue, sought
momentary relief in the restroom of a neighborhood tavern.
Sheridan, considering the temper
of the establishment, elected to
wait outside while police arrived
to apprehend the prowler.
The Northern District Police
and the Ace Elastic bandage
company combined to bring the
situation well under control. The
suspect claimed that, he had entered the woman's parked car
looking "for a peaceful night's
rest."
On Tuesday, October 19 in the
County Court, North Maryland
District at 9:00 A.M., the suspect
was found guilty of vagrancy
and is currently serving a sixtyday sentence in the city jail.

Dawidowicz and Harding then

Although it was finely agreed

number of SDS members expressed disapproval of the invitation
at a gathering Thersday of approximately half of the chapter.
It was felt that attending the
closed session with Rusk might
be construed as tacit SDS approval of such seminars, which
the organization has strongly
denounced. Furthermore, some
believed that the hour-long
period would result in little more
than a statement by Rusk of Administration policy, with little
opportunity for positive contributions by the others present.
Finally. Dawidowicz stated, it
was suggested that the Hopkins
administration was attempting
to placate SDS, and that it had
only granted a question-answer
period at Rusk's lecture at the
last moment, and as a result of
strong pressure from SDS.
Ross Jones, executive assistant to Hopkins President Milton
Eisenhower, explained that the
Invitation was "a genuine effort
to allow representatives from
SDS to participate in an interesting and beneficial discussion
with Secretary Rusk." The undergraduates would have been
admitted, he said, since SDS has
exhibited such intense interest
in Rusk's visit. He also stated
that the two SDS members had
been chosen for no other reason
than their prominence in SIXS
activities at Hopkins.

HOT DAMN. VIET-NAM
If Dean Husk was to be the Pied Piper of Washington, to appease the Hopkins intelligentsia who have
plagued him as did the "rats of Hamlin", to bring the
dissenting scholars into the swing of Viet Nam Policy,
then his horn was surely out of tune; for in the formal
part of his speech, he didn't blow anything but his cool.
This doesn't mean that his appearance did not
bring on a festive Friday the fifteenth. But it does mean
that midst the clamour of the gala political afternoon,
few people paid any attention to the Pied's feeble horn.
It was Internatipnal Peace Week and 'experts" predicted that Athens, Paris, Pittsburgh and Baltimore
would he the stage for one of the largest Communist
rallies in History.
There were week-long rumors that the Communists
had infiltrated the Hopkins' radical ranks, and the News
American, "the people's paper", took advantage of a
sympathetic local public to splash what looked to them
like red all around the primmed Homewood green.
A little old lady, her face liberally roughed red,
cut a mean and rather contrary political rug as she
marched, American flag in hand, into the ring of protestors.
Everyone got a laugh out of the young fellow who
stuck a sign in the air which put Communism down in
very obscene terms; probably his was the only attestation that everyone fully understood or at least agreed
with. Ile was later detained by the police.
And at the same time that Charles Capper, in a
post-address forum in Levering Hall, was reading the
writing on the wall in technicolor, and Dr. Peabody was
reading from a Washington-reflected mirror in black
and white, the Secretary of State, Dean Rusk had made
the following announcement:
"Cooperative research in radiation sterilization Technique is resulting in the elimination of the screwworm from doe Island of Curacao, and the United States
scientists are currently participating in studies in Central America, in which irradiation techniques are being
employed in the control of the Mediterranean fruit fly."
The audience snickered behind the Piper's back.

MOTOR SPORTS

Road Test:'49 Ford Convertible

...

One too many mornings follows one too many beers

With the advent of new and
radical designs on the American
automotive market, one is often
tempted to seek the sure and
the steady, the car with conventional drive, which offers the
many comforts of modern technology, yet can be depended
upon to go. One such is the famous classic which has become
an automotive legend in its own
time, the world famous 1949
Super Torque SSK flat head V-8,
independent suspension Ford
Deluxe, sometimes
Roadster
known as the '49 Ford.
In order to ,acquaint our readers with the many wonders of
this car, it was our rare privilege to drive such a vehicle, since
only a few are in existence. This
was not a limited production car
by any means, so the scarcity of
the model is accounted to hoarding by collectors and museums,
as well as scrap metal processing
concerns.
The first thing one notices
upon approaching the automobile, besides the smell of oil, is
the striking design of the coachwork, and the obvious care with
which the automobile was con-

structed. On notices that in the
ancient Ford tradition, the body
has rotted out in a symmetrical,
artistically coherent pattern,
giving the car great unity of design. The rusted-through areas
serve to ventilate the passenger
and engine compartments with a
continuous flow of fresh, cold
air—a welcome change, we note,
from the artiflcally-treated air
one is forced to breathe in modern automobiles. The paint is, of
course, the finest lacquer, and
its unique patina would be hard
to duplicate in any but the most
expensive auto finishes. The
hood ornament, a classic in
its own right, is the famous
Ford "Plastic Hunk", so popular in the late forties and early
fifties—up to the Civil War.
Its design represents the freedom
of speed and motion, and the
integrity inherent in this proud
steed of the highways.
No discussion of the outer car
would be complete without a
thorough examination of the fine
removable top. Many radical design features have been incorporated in its production. In
answer to an oft-heard corn-

plaint that the top refuses to go
down through motor malfunction, the possibility of such malfunction has been precluded by
the elimination of the motor. In
a sweeping change in top construction concept, Ford's top
goes up and down by hand.
Great on all but the rainiest
days. An equally radical design
feature is the use of dependable
grey canvas to replace easilytearing vinyl. Kudos on these
two great accomplishments.
Let us now turn to the technical aspects of this rarest of
all great cars. The motor is the
famous flat-head V-8, which
turns 428 b.h.p. at 7200 RPM,but
unfortunately has its redline at
The
3000.
great
potential
In this design, it seems, was

=-REPUBLICAN BIAS

The Beginning Or The End
By JEOPFRY LEBAR
The Republican failure at the
Polls in 1964 may have been the
beginning or the ending of a
Political party. The mere fact
that it is in the past does not
remove it from the present. It
Will affect future American political history as much as have
the gmat wars and depressions.
The "linage" of the Republican
Party cannot be restored to "the
Party of responsibility" now by
Madison avenue techniques or
even by our able political medieine man, Ray Bliss.
The Republican party needs
the intellectual and collegiate
Mind to express its thoughts. It
needs the minds and plans of
those who read this column. The
American political system needs
the eloquence of an Adlai
Stevenson or the prosaic turn of
the word of a John Kennedy
froni the Republican side of the
aisle. We, Young Republicans,
as authors of this column, intend to treat the daily issues
from a quasi-intellectual view
Point.
The Republican party Is a
Political party whose sole concern is with the governing of
this country and its relations
With other countries. The RePublican party is not an organization created to grind out dogma on theoretical issues. Its doctrines cannot and should not extend out of the practical and
Material. With this attitude, a
Political party will lose most of
its Intellectual support from the
beginning. However, the ideals,
beliefs, and convictions of the
individual can be transformed
into reality through political
Parties. The Democratic Party,
although not completely successful at this, has kindled the enthusiasm of the intellectual
community more than the RePublican party. Enough for political philosophy
Dr. Mandelbaum, Professor in
"Philosophic Classics and Problems" (courses which I heartily

recommend) once remarked to
me that if one thoroughly learned moral and ethical philosophy,
political philosophy could be
figured out on a slide-rule. All
the more power to him.
Let's start with the issue of
honesty in government. This issue could hardly save Barry
Goldwater's campaign from the
stigma of World War III, segregation, or poverty for everyone
over 65. But historically and
certainly in practice today, the
Republican party has been the
cleaner of the two parties. The
absconding New York mayor,
Jimmie Walker, was succeeded
by a LaGuardia. The Hague's,
the Prentergast's, the Tweed's,
the De Sapio's, and the Bobby
Baker's are in the tradition of
machine politics and all happen
to be Democrats. The Republicans cannot be particularly
proud of the Ulysses Grant administration after the Civil War,
or the Sherman Adams vicuna
coat incident. By and large, however, the openness of political
opinion and the unregimented,
individualistic attitude of Republicans does not lead to absolute
control of the party in any one
place. Therefore, corruption under the eagle eye of the Democratic leaders is quite a difficult
thing for Republicans.
But does this really matter?
Read the speeches of President
Johnson
and
other Democratic leaders. Their platforms
do not include promises of clean
government. They don't deny

PAGE SEVEN

NEWS-LETTER

I

scandals in their programs for
the impoverished: Mobilisation
for Youth, HARYOU, etc. Johnson never assures his people that
his administration is made up of
men free from temptation. Apparently he doesn't have to. The
people are basically uninterested.
Scandal and corruption have
been the cost of progress in the
past and the habit has not been
broken.
A Republican victory in the
field of ethics in government
would probably be the most
vital victory of all. If Republicans were elected and agreed to
carry out every social program
of the Democratic party in an
honest and professional way, the
Republican party would have
much to be proud of and the
country would have much to
gain.
Rather than attempting to
destroy any social legislation
that our Democratic brethren
may have stumbled upon, the
Republican aim should be to
clean it up, make it just, remove
the "pork-barrel", elminate the
fraud, and uncover the Bobby
Bakers. It isn't glamorous. It
isn't very conservative or very
liberal or very exciting. It may
not get many votes, but it will
mean better government. And,
as the car owner quickly learns
the difference in quality between
the Allstate and Prudential Insurance Company, the voter will
learn the differences between the
quality of the Democrat and
Republican parties.

Malone Tops
Fathers Record

Labor And Johnson's Great Consensus

I

by CHARLES CAPPER
With the emergence of the national corporation around the
turn of the century, the trend
toward a progressively centralized economy marked the inevitable corollary of American industrialization. The competition
of small firms gave way to the
concentration of the basic decisions of production and distribution into a small number of
corporations.
proBefore World War
gressives looked to government
as a force capable of ensuring
the "public responsibility" of
corporations. But even the progressive Wilson administration,
In spite of its election pronouncements, quickly realized what
Theodore Roosevelt had learned
—that the government, lacking
any real economic power of its
own, could only co-operate with,
and not coerce, the corporate
rulers of American economic life.
Even during the first deof
Franklin
years
pression
Roosevelt's administration, the

government could experiment
with programs of social legislation only so far as they did not
threaten corporation rule.
In fact, Roosevelt's first legislation, the key to his first New
Deal recovery program—the National Industrial Recovery Act—
was concerned with legalizing,
co-operating with, and helping
to extend the concentration of
economic power into the hands
of progressively fewer corporations.
But the 30's also gave birth to
the first real challenge to the
economic power of the giant
corporations—organized labor on
an industry wide basis.
In making economic decisions,
such as wages and working conditions, corporations had to take
into increasingly greater account
the power of their organized
workers, wielding the weapon of
strike.
But even these economic decisions in a highly centralized
and industrialized economy had

to be viewed in the context of
larger economic and political
questions. Higher wages secured
from an employer become meaningless for workers thrown out
of work because of technological
unemployment.
The right to strike, the ultimate economic .power of organized labor, becomes meaningless
when the government, as under
the Taft-Hartley Act, continually
intervenes to suppress strikes in
major industries.
Consequently, in order to preserve its power as a labor movement, labor is forced to act politically—to preserve those gains
made across the bargaining table
and to gain those benefits only a
healthy economy can provide.
The political mechanism traditionally utilized by labor since
the 30's has been the Democratic
party.
Without discussing the historical evolution of this relationship
between the Democratic party
and the organized labor movement, we can only focus on the
most recent developments in
terms of the Johnson administration.
On every Great Society bill—
poverty, education. medicare,
beautification — labor worked
hard for President Johnson. In
return labor sought three 'goals—
repeal of Section 14b of the
Taft-Hartley Act (which now
permits states to outlaw compulsory unionism), higher minimum wage, and liberalization of
the unemployment compensation
system. They got none.

The reaction of labor leaders
to this political orphanage was
summed up by one labor lobbyist
at a meeting of leaders on October 11: "President Johnson has
passed a lot of bills, but they're
all concensus bills — backed by
business as well as labor. He's
not pushing a single bill really
tough for big business to swallow." But even more important
than this recognition of labor's
political impotence within the
Democratic party is the leadership's rationalization and remedy for such impotence.
In the first place, the strength
of organized labor has been significantly lessened since World
War II. Union membership has
often declined in relation to the
work force; organizing campaigns (particularly in the potentially powerful white collar
sector) have been weak. Related
to this quantitative decline has
been a decline of militancy.
Union leaders cannot rally the
political militancy of the rankand-file against Johnson because
these same leaders are almost
daily involved in suppressing
shop militancy, selling company
contracts to discontented workers, and generally playing the
role of Johnson's ambassadors to
the working class. And finally,
the labor leadership is so tied to
the Democratic party that the
ultimate threat to Johnson—a
party bolt—is out of the question.
As the Washington correspondents, Evans and Novack, point
out, "With all its grievances, big
labor isn't about to say anything
out loud criticizing President
Johnson ... It has nowhere else
to go." More correctly, labor
leadership has nowhere else to
go.
Whether or not the rank-andfile workers of the unions continue to tolerate this organizational stagnation, suppression of
economic militancy, and political impotence, is another question.

By JIM MONGIARDO
What do you do when you
enter Hopkins if your father was
an All American lacrosse player
in the golden days of Bluejay lacrosse? Quite simply, you boot
your way to All American soccer recognition in the fall and
achieve All American honors on
the lacrosse team in the spring.
better
Mallonee,
Stephen
known as "Lucky", has run up an
impressive athletic record in both
soccer and lacrosse before and
after coming to Hopkins. The
blond, sturdy senior, is serving
this year as co-captain of both
the varsity squads he is on.
Lucky lu.s always been a Baltimore resident. In twelve years
at the Park School, he achieved
first team All Maryland recognition four times. Three of those
were as center halfback for the
soccer team and once as midfielder for the lacrogse team. He
was also an honorable mention
All Maryland basketball player.
Mallonee's training in lacrosse
at Park came from Joe Seivold.
former All-America from Washington College.
Coming to Hopkins with quite
a tradition to live up to, Lucky.
who was given that nickname
even before being born, participated on the soccer, basketball.
and lacrosse teams his freshmen
year.
During his sophomore year,
Mallonee tied a Hopkins record
by kicking four goals in a soccer game. In fact, all of those
came in one period, as the Jays
came from behind to win a 4-3
thriller from Delaware.
The following season. Lucky
was elected co-captain of the
soccer team. He was selected for
his play as right halfback to
both the All Mason-Dixon Conference and All South Conference
teams. The year before he had
been an honorable mention All
American.
Last spring, the senior
achieved what has father had
done before him and was named
to the first midfield team of the
All America lacrosse squad.

By BARRON WORMSER
Boasting an impressive 3-0 log,
the varsity crosscountry team
will face a tough Franklin and
Marshall squad tomorrow afternoon at Homewood.
As the two teams are evenly
matched; the physical condition
of John Sopka, who is nursing
an injury, could play an important role in determining the final
Outcome.
The Jays, who met Gettysburg
Wednesday, notched a pair of
wins last Saturday in a triangular meet against Haverford
and Drexel. Sparked by the brilliant running of Kevin Murphy,
the harriers turned back Haverford, 26-31; and Drexel, 23-33.
Murphy's determined performance was especially exceptional
due to the fact that he had
missed practice for the entire
week because of an ankle injury.

The third win in the Blue Jays'
victory column was the result
of the decision of the Hopkins
and Loyola directors concerning
the disputed October 9th meet
with the Greyhounds. The .claim
lodged against Hopkins runner
John Sopka was turned down,
thus giving the Jays a 27-30 victory.
The coach of the undefeated
Polanowski,
Ed
hill'n'dalers,
stated that he was very pleased
with the team's showing so far
and was especially happy about
the great improvement shown by
Jack Loomis and Cliff Cyr.

other runners who have shown
good potential. As the varsity
contingent will lose three of its
top men in June, the performance of the freshmen is especially important.

Tuesday and meet Bainbridge
Prep, today at Homewood. In
racking up their initial win over

eight places. Top time was
posted by Jeff Lauren, who negotiated the course in 10:38.
